subtask1.query: Use reliable NBA sources to identify the player who, in a single season, was selected as both an All-Star and a member of the All-Defensive First Team, and was subsequently traded for a package that included a player who had previously made the All-Rookie Second Team with the franchise trading him away. This included player also shares a surname with a historical figure famously styled as 'The Great'. State the player, the specific season in which the dual honors were achieved, and the trade context, producing a narrative answer file under workspace/. Note: All context is accurate through September 2025.
subtask1.deliverables: subtask1.md that identifies the qualifying player, explains how they satisfy the specific season honors, and cites evidence for the trade connection involving the player with the 'The Great' surname.
subtask1.rubric:
- 0 points: Player is not Paul George or the explanation conflicts with the ground truth (e.g., wrong trade partner).
- 5 points: Names Paul George but fails to identify the correct trade package or the specific historical name reference.
- 8 points: Identifies Paul George and the 2018–19 season, but the explanation of the trade return (Shai Gilgeous-Alexander) or the 'Alexander the Great' connection is vague.
- 10 points: Fully matches the Paul George ground truth: cites his 2018–19 All-Star/All-Defensive First Team season, and details the 2019 trade to the Clippers which included Shai Gilgeous-Alexander (All-Rookie Second Team w/ Clippers, shares surname with Alexander the Great).

subtask2.query: Using the same environment and references, determine which player won a regular-season MVP during the same career phase as winning at least three scoring titles, has led the league in both scoring and assists in separate seasons, and was later traded for a package that included a player who had won Rookie of the Year with the franchise acquiring the MVP. Document the seasons and the trade proof. Note: All context is accurate through September 2025.
subtask2.deliverables: subtask2.md that presents the identified player, detailing their MVP year, the count of scoring titles, the specific season they led in assists, and the identity of the former Rookie of the Year included in the trade package.
subtask2.rubric:
- 0 points: Any answer other than James Harden, or fails to validate the MVP/Scoring/Assist combination.
- 5 points: Mentions Harden but leaves the timeline vague or excludes the specific trade component involving the former Rookie of the Year.
- 8 points: Covers Harden with most milestones yet lacks specific citation for the assist title or the trade details.
- 10 points: Perfect alignment with the James Harden ground truth—lists 2017–18 MVP, three scoring titles (2018-2020), 2016–17 assist title, and the 2022 trade to the 76ers involving Ben Simmons (who won ROY with the 76ers).

subtask3.query: Identify the player who captured Rookie of the Year, accumulated at least four scoring titles, earned a regular-season MVP prior to winning a Finals MVP, and changed teams via a sign-and-trade transaction where an All-Star player was effectively exchanged for him to his former team. Provide a rigorous explanation file. Note: All context is accurate through September 2025.
subtask3.deliverables: subtask3.md that identifies the qualifying player, details their Rookie of the Year season and scoring title achievements, analyzes the chronology of their MVP and Finals MVP awards, and explains the specific roster movement involving the All-Star player.
subtask3.rubric:
- 0 points: Player selection disagrees with the Kevin Durant ground truth or omits multiple required achievements.
- 5 points: States Durant but fails to clarify the correct order of MVP/FMVP or the sign-and-trade details.
- 8 points: Provides Durant and most evidence but misses the specific details of the All-Star player involved in the exchange.
- 10 points: Completely consistent with the Kevin Durant ground truth: ROY (2008), 4 Scoring Titles, MVP (2014) won before FMVPs (2017, 2018), and the 2019 sign-and-trade that sent D'Angelo Russell (2019 All-Star) to the Warriors.

subtask4.query: Determine the player who has made multiple NBA Finals appearances without ever winning a regular-season MVP, holds the NBA regular-season record for most three-pointers made in a single game, has never averaged more than 23 points per game in a full season, and was teammates with a #1 overall draft pick who had earned an All-Conference First Team nod in college. Produce a written justification file. Note: All context is accurate through September 2025.
subtask4.deliverables: subtask4.md that identifies the qualifying player and details the evidence for each requirement, including the specific three-point record, regular season scoring statistics, Finals history, and the collegiate credentials of the #1 pick teammate.
subtask4.rubric:
- 0 points: Answer diverges from the Klay Thompson ground truth or lacks discussion of the specific records.
- 5 points: Identifies Thompson but leaves requirements unsubstantiated (e.g., fails to check the PPG limit or teammate credentials).
- 8 points: Thompson is backed by most facts but misses the specific citation of the 3-point record or the teammate's college honor.
- 10 points: Flawless correlation with the Klay Thompson ground truth: cites the 14 3-pointers record (2018), multiple titles, career high PPG < 23 (22.3), and teammate Andrew Wiggins (#1 Pick, All-Big 12 First Team at Kansas).

subtask5.query: Aggregate the findings from subtasks 1–4. Construct a final validation report that lists the four identified players, verifying whether they meet the specific conditions outlined in the previous queries. Work Create a structured JSON report. Note: All context is accurate through September 2025.
subtask5.deliverables: summary.json contains objects for subtasks 1–4 with keys: submitted_player, matches_criteria (boolean), and verification_notes (array detailing the evidence regarding the specific clauses requested).
subtask5.rubric:
- 0 points: Fails to include the identified players or omits one or more subtasks.
- 5 points: Provides partial data but lacks match flags or per-clause notes.
- 8 points: Covers all subtasks with correct identifications yet contains schema gaps or insufficient detail.
- 10 points: Exactly mirrors the real-world ground truth (Paul George, James Harden, Kevin Durant, Klay Thompson) by listing all four subtasks with the specified structure, accurate match flags, and descriptive condition notes.
